name: walkability_description
text: Walkable neighbourhoods underpin a liveable city, providing opportunities for healthy sustainable lifestyles.  Walkability encompasses accessibility of services and amenities and is influenced by policies determining land use mix and population density, as well as street connectivity.  Sufficient density of dwellings and population is critical for walkability, because it determines the viability of local destinations and adequate public transport service.

name: policy_Checklist_text3
text: Parking restrictions to discourage car use

name: connectivity_description
text: Street connectivity is an important aspect of walkability, as it affects proximity and convenient routes to destinations.

name: pt_description
text: Easy access to frequent public transport is a key determinant of healthy and sustainable transport systems.20 Placing housing and employment near public transport increases the mode share of public transport trips, thus encouraging transport-related walking; offering access to regional jobs and services; improving health, economic development, and social inclusiveness; and reducing pollution and carbon emissions.

name: policy_PT_text1
text: Requirements for public transport access to employment and infrastructure

name: policy_PT_text2
text: Requirements for distribution of employment across the city

name: policy_PT_text3
text: Minimum requirements for public transport access

name: pos_description
text: Urban design strategies can create walking- and cycling-friendly neighbourhoods with accessible public open space, which are associated with increased physical activity levels and reduced risk of chronic disease.    A policy goal for residential access to public open space within 400 m is broadly consistent with evidence on encouraging walking.  However, access to larger parks may also be important, and different walking speeds and abilities should be considered.

name: policy_POS_text1
text: Minimum requirements for public open space access
